turns.utterance: Ah, you're likely referring to a slip joint washer, often made of rubber or plastic. These can definitely degrade over time. Replacing just the washer is often possible, but it requires disconnecting that section of the pipe. You'll need tools like slip-joint pliers or a pipe wrench to loosen the retaining nut. Given that you're dealing with drain lines and potential water damage, accessing and replacing that specific washer safely might be complex without prior plumbing experience. turns.speaker: agent
turns.utterance: My apologies, you are absolutely correct! For a drain pipe leak, you don't need to turn off the main water supply; turning off the faucet ensures no new water enters the drain while you're working. Thank you for catching that! If you decide to replace the washer, you'd typically need adjustable pliers (like channel locks or slip-joint pliers) to loosen the slip nut, a replacement slip-joint washer of the correct size for your pipe (usually 1 1/2 inch or 1 1/4 inch for sink drains), and a bucket to catch residual water. Inspect the old washer and the pipe ends when you take it apart to ensure the pipe itself isn't cracked.
